ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Not much really. The course just gives you a ton of work but doesn't teach you the concepts you need to solve them.
I learned how to Integrate and solve derivatives.
I learned a lot about Calculus I, I think I can do well in Calculus II.
How to differentiate functions, integrals, and understand formulas and be able to use them as justification for my answers.
A in depth understanding of calculus
The ability to problem solve word problems and treat math like a language rather than numerically.
I learned a lot in this class. I now understand the reasoning behind my calculus skills and how I can apply them in my everyday life.
I learned how to take the concepts from class to apply them to More difficult problems.
I learned how to apply fundamental ideas of Calculus to more complex problems and real life examples.
I learned how to use my teachers office hours to my advantage.
I had a solid understanding on derivatives, and integrals with their applications on various aspects.
Mainly, I learned how to navigate QR courses in general at Yale.
It was a good calc refresher.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
1. Workload - Ximera could be useful but there is just simply too much work. The problem sets have way too many questions in them. In the end, students end up rushing through the PSET without really thinking the solutions through. Cut down on the number of questions per PSET; it would make the workload a lot more manageable and give students some time to do the work

2. Course instructors/ Lectures: almost no worked examples were given during class. All of it was theoretical/conceptual without any examples being worked through--I will say there were some examples but these were the most basic ones. Try work through some advanced questions in class so students understand how the concepts can be applied to harder questions.
I think the review sessions could have been improved.

Strengths: workload manageable, lots of accessible help 
Weaknesses: lectures were often confusing and not engaging
The weaknesses are the differences between who teaches you the material
A strength of this course is that it forces the student to know how to apply the theorems of calculus and explain them in terms of different problems. This expands the view of calculus.
More problems related to the actual topics would've been helpful but the professors were great at teaching. I just found myself doing problems on the test that were never discussed in class

Strength - I believe that I learned a lot any my professor was very good at describing the topics and mathematics. 
Weakness - I came in late to the course and felt overwhelmed before the first midterm. There was not a ton of support, but I figured it out.
The weaknesses is the teaching style i think it can be more engaging for students.
I think the problem tests were a lot harder than the exams and in general the psets were very hard to do by yourself so this encourages relying on others for help a little too much.
The teachers need to overall be prepared to communicate better in English. The language barrier is a big issue when it comes to teaching the basic concepts in class.
It was perfect.

This course is a good overview of calc 1. The biggest weakness of this course is how easy it is to get problem set answers in peer tutor office hours, without learning the material fully. More assessments, like low-stake quizzes, would be useful for students to know where they stand.
Strengths: Makes it hard to fall through the cracks. You are always being forced to use the new knowledge you learned. Weakness: If you have taken calc before it may be boring.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not at all. Math 112 is meant to be the most basic calculus course, so working through the concepts instead of reading off a textbook theory would help.
Yes! There are many teachers but mine was engaging and knew the material very well. The support system, including peer tutors and office hours, were plentiful and helpful.
No, it was very challenging for me but that was also because I am not great at math.
You do learn many techniques and it is a requirement for many majors.
Yes
Only if they have a good grasp of calculus already
No I wouldn't because of it's level of difficulty. If no student has experienced a math class before then this isnt for them. It moves extremely fast and teaches math as if it were a language.
Yes, I believe that everyone should have a conceptual understanding of calculus. I am an economics major and believe that it is going to be very important in my future courses.
Yes it is a very good basic calculus course.
Yes I would it is a good course that provides a good base of knowledge in math for other classes.

I would not recommend this course. It is not taught well enough to move at the pace it does. in addition the section you are in has too much of an impact on how the class goes for you because each ta is very differently prepared
I would recommend. This course is a great way to learn the basics of calculus.
I would recommend this course to other students, but only if they are sure that they will need to know this material for their future academic endeavors.
Yes, it is good to know calculus.
